Lesson Plan
1.Engage
• Teacher’s Role 1.Set the Stage with a Quiz Game 1. Prepare a slideshow or use an online quiz platform (e.g., Kahoot, Quizizz) to show images of famous landmarks, monuments, or museum logos. Examples include: 1. Eiffel Tower (France) 2. Great Wall of China (China) 3. Smithsonian Institution logo (USA) 4. Louvre Museum logo (France) 2. Ask students to identify the landmark/museum and its location. 2.Facilitate a Group Discussion 1. After the quiz, ask students: 1. "Why do you think some monuments or museums are more well-known internationally than others?" 2. "What factors could influence their recognition?" 2. Guide the conversation to cover factors like historical importance, cultural significance, media exposure, and tourism. 3.Introduce Technology's Role 1. Pose the final question: 1. "How do you think technology can change our experience of learning about monuments and museums today?" 2. Provide examples to spark ideas (e.g., virtual tours, interactive apps, social media exposure). 4.Connect to the Next Phase 1. Conclude by explaining that in the next part of the lesson, students will explore how museums use technology and storytelling to represent cultures and share important stories.t
• Student’s Role 1.Participate in the Quiz 1. Actively guess the landmarks or museums and discuss their locations and significance. 2.Reflect and Discuss 1. Share their ideas during the group discussion about why some sites are better known than others. 2. Reflect on how technology might enhance their ability to learn about and connect with cultural heritage. 3.Prepare for Exploration 1. Engage with the questions to build curiosity and prepare for deeper exploration in the next phase of the lesson.

• Strategy to Implement 1.Interactive Quiz Game 1. Use a visual quiz format to keep students engaged. If using technology, tools like Kahoot or Google Slides with clickable answers work well. 2. Display 8–10 famous landmarks/museum logos, starting with easy ones (e.g., the Eiffel Tower) and gradually including less familiar examples. 2.Think-Pair-Share for Questions 1. After the quiz, pose the discussion questions and let students: 1. Think individually for 1-2 minutes. 2. Pair with a partner to discuss their thoughts. 3. Share responses with the whole class.

2. Explore
 TeacherRole: 1. Introduce the Exploration Task 1. Explain that students will use the Google Arts & Culture Partners platform to investigate how museums represent different cultures and tell important stories. 2. Provide clear instructions on navigating the platform, such as searching for museums, browsing exhibits, and identifying artifacts or stories. 2.Guide Students’ Focus 1. Provide guiding questions to help students focus their exploration. For example: 1. How do museums showcase cultural heritage? 2. What types of artifacts or stories are used to represent different cultures? 3. What message or theme does the exhibit convey? 2. Encourage students to note their observations and record specific examples. 3.Facilitate Inquiry 1. Circulate and check in with students as they explore. 2. Encourage them to think critically about what they’re seeing. For example: 1. Why do you think the museum chose to display this artifact? 2. How does the exhibit make you feel, and what might its creators want you to learn?
 ExpectedFrom Students: 1.Engage with the Platform
1. Students explore the Google Arts & Culture Partners platform, choosing at least 2-3 museums or exhibits to investigate. 2. They take notes on: 1. The culture(s) represented. 2. The artifacts, artworks, or storytelling methods used. 3. Themes or messages conveyed by the exhibit. 2.Record Observations 1. Students write down specific examples (e.g., "The British Museum’s collection of African masks highlights the diversity of artistic traditions across the continent"). 2. They reflect on how these elements contribute to cultural understanding. 3.Prepare to Share 1. Students prepare a summary of their findings, focusing on: 1. What they learned about how museums represent cultures. 2. Ideas or inspirations for how they might represent similar stories in their own "museum."

Activity Worksheet or Guiding Questions You might provide a worksheet or list of prompts to scaffold their exploration: 1.Museum/Exhibit Name: 2.Culture Represented: 3.Artifacts or Stories Observed: 4.How is the story of this culture told (e.g., visuals, text, audio)? 5.What message or theme is the museum conveying? 6.How could you use similar methods to represent a culture or story in your own museum?

3. Explain
• Teacher’s Role
1.Introduce the Resources 1. Start by explaining that students will watch a video, read an article, and explore an interactive website. These resources show how technology transforms the way we experience museums and cultural sites. 2. Provide an overview of the key points they should look for, such as: 1. How technology improves engagement and accessibility in museums. 2. Examples of technologies used (e.g., VR, AR, interactive guides). 3. The impact of these technologies on visitors’ experiences. 2.Facilitate Engagement with the Video 1. Play the YouTube video, pausing at key moments to clarify or emphasize important points. For example: 1. Pause to discuss specific technologies mentioned (e.g., AR or VR). 2. Ask, “What do you think makes these technologies exciting or effective in a museum setting?” 3.Guide Reading of the Article 1. Assign the article either as an in-class reading or homework, depending on time constraints. 2. Provide students with a reading guide or annotation prompts, such as: 1. Highlight examples of technologies mentioned. 2. Underline the benefits of technology for different types of visitors. 3. Write down one new thing you learned about museum experiences. 4.Introduce the Interactive Exploration 1. Share the Mused website link and explain that they’ll explore “Inside the Great Pyramid.” Encourage them to take notes on: 1. How the interactive experience provides a deeper understanding of the site. 2. Features they found most engaging or surprising. 2. After the activity, discuss how this differs from visiting a physical museum. 5.Lead a Reflection 1. Hold a class discussion or ask students to write a short response connecting all three resources. 2. Pose reflection questions: 1. “Which technology do you think is most effective for enhancing museum experiences, and why?” 2. “How do these innovations make cultural heritage accessible to more people?”

• Student’s Role 1.Watch the Video 1. Actively watch the video and identify specific technologies or ideas that stand out. 2. Participate in class discussions about key points. 2.Read the Article 1. Engage with the article by annotating or taking notes as directed. 2. Share insights or questions during a follow-up discussion. 3.Explore the Interactive Website 1. Navigate the virtual experience of the Great Pyramid, noting features they found engaging or effective in storytelling. 2. Compare this experience with traditional museum visits. 4.Participate in Reflection 1. Share their thoughts and reflections during the discussion or in a written response. 2. Connect the video, article, and website exploration to broader ideas about how technology enhances cultural experiences.
• Strategies to implement 1.Multisensory Engagement 1. Use a variety of media formats (video, text, and interactive exploration) to cater to different learning styles. 2. Encourage students to imagine themselves as museum visitors while engaging with these resources. 2.Break It Into Segments 1. Watch the video together and discuss as a class. 2. Allow students to read the article independently or in pairs to encourage peer discussion. 3. Use the website exploration as an individual or small-group activity for hands-on engagement. 3.Gamify the Reflection 1. After completing all three activities, use tools like Padlet or Jamboard to let students post their favorite examples or create a “technology battle” where they vote for the most innovative technology. 4.Connect to Real Life 1. Ask students if they’ve ever visited a museum with advanced technology or experienced a virtual exhibit. 2. Have them brainstorm how their local museums could implement similar technologies.

4. Elaborate.
• Teacher’s Role 1.Facilitate the Assessment 1. Distribute the quiz to evaluate students’ understanding of technology's role in museums. 2. Discuss the answers with the class to ensure clarity and address misconceptions. 2.Introduce the Activity 1. Explain that students will: 1. Search for an existing 3D model of a landmark in Tinkercad. 2. Export the model in the appropriate format. 3. Upload the model to Augment to create an AR experience. 2. Demonstrate the steps for searching, exporting, and uploading. 3.Provide Support 1. Assist students as they search for landmarks and export models. 2. Ensure everyone can upload their models to Augment and explore its AR features. 4.Encourage Reflection 1. Lead a discussion or have students write about how AR technology enhances learning and engagement in museums.
• Student’s Role 1.Complete the Assessment 1. Answer the quiz questions to evaluate their understanding of how technology is utilized in museums. 2. Participate in a class review to discuss the answers. 2.Search for a Landmark in Tinkercad 1. Use Tinkercad to search for a 3D model of a famous landmark (e.g., Eiffel Tower, Statue of Liberty). 2. Select a model that is ready for export. 3.Export the Landmark Model 1. Export the model in a format compatible with Augment (e.g., .obj or .stl). 4.Create an AR Experience 1. Upload the exported model to the Augment platform. 2. Explore the AR version of the landmark, noting how it could be used in a museum context. 5.Reflect on the Process 1. Share their AR landmark with the class and explain how AR can enhance visitor engagement and understanding in museums.

Assessment Questions and Answers 1.How is technology commonly utilized in museums? 1. A) To entertain visitors 2. B) To improve visitor experience (Correct Answer) 3. C) To reduce the number of exhibits 2.How do apps benefit museum visitors? 1. A) They feel more connected to exhibits 2. B) They offer detailed information on exhibits (Correct Answer) 3. C) They limit the time spent in each room 3.What is the main purpose of using technology in museums? 1. A) To save energy costs 2. C) To make learning more interactive (Correct Answer) 4.Why is augmented reality used in museums? 1. A) To add virtual lighting to exhibits 2. B) To add to real-world exhibits (Correct Answer) 3. C) To control lighting in exhibits

5. Evaluate
• Student Task At-Home Project: Using block-coding software, students will create an interactive game that highlights their country’s history and landmarks. Game Requirements: 1.Historical Content: 1. Include at least two key historical events or stories. 2. Explain their significance within the game. 2.Monument Showcase: 1. Include at least two famous landmarks and describe their importance in the country’s culture or history. 3.Interactivity: 1. Include engaging elements such as: 1. Quizzes to test knowledge about history or landmarks. 2. Challenges or mini-games related to the events or monuments. 4.Design and Functionality: 1. The game should be easy to navigate and visually appealing. 2. Incorporate animations, sound effects, or other multimedia elements to enhance engagement.
• Teacher Role 1.Explain the Task 1. Provide a clear explanation of the task, showing examples of simple educational games created using block-coding software. 2. Highlight the importance of creativity and alignment with the project requirements. 2.Offer Guidance 1. Share resources such as tutorials or templates for Scratch, Tynker, or mBlock. 2. Be available to answer technical questions about using the block-coding tools. 3.Evaluate Submissions 1. Use the rubric (below) to assess the projects based on historical accuracy, creativity, interactivity, and functionality.
